questions.question: I waited for my friend until he ……………….
questions.description: A past tense in the main clause is usually followed by a past tense in the subordinate clause.

questions.question: He ran as quickly as he …………………..
questions.description: Could is the past tense form of can. A past tense in the main clause is usually followed by a past tense in the subordinate clause.

questions.question: He ran away because he ………………. afraid.
questions.description: Was is the past simple form of is. A past tense in the main clause is usually followed by a past tense in the subordinate clause.

questions.question: He was so tired that he ………………… barely stand.
After the rain was over, the sun ………………… out again.
questions.description: Either shone or shined is possible here.

questions.question: His health ………………….. since he left the city.
questions.description: Perfect tenses are preferred with since and for.

questions.question: Whenever we ………………… we talk of old times.
questions.description: We use the simple present to talk about habits or routines.

questions.question: Wherever he …………………., people gathers to listen.
questions.description: We use the simple present to talk about habits or routines.

questions.question: Galileo maintained that the earth ..................... round the sun.
questions.description: A past tense in the main clause may be followed by a present tense in the subordinate clause when the subordinate clause expresses a universal truth.

questions.question: Newton discovered that the force of gravitation ...................... apples fall.
questions.description: A past tense in the main clause may be followed by a present tense in the subordinate clause when the subordinate clause expresses a universal truth.

questions.question: He rested his horse because it …………………
He said that he …………………. the examination.
questions.description: When the reporting verb is in the past tense, all present tenses of the direct speech changes into the corresponding past tense.
